greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write 2n-1 = p+q with q practical, p and q-p both prime.
comment: This has been verified for n up to 10^7.
As p+q=2p+(q-p), the conjecture implies Lemoine's conjecture related to A046927.
Zhi-Wei Sun also conjectured that any integer n>2 can be written as p+q, where p is a prime,  one of q and q+1 is prime and another of q and q+1 is practical.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
G. Melfi, On two conjectures about practical numbers, J. Number Theory 56 (1996) 205-210 [MR96i:11106].
Zhi-Wei Sun, Conjectures involving primes and quadratic forms, arXiv:1211.1588 [math.NT], 2012-2017.
example: a(9)=1 since 2*9-1=5+12 with 12 practical, 5 and 12-5 both prime.
mathematica: Con[n_]:=Con[n]=Sum[If[Part[Part[f[n], s+1], 1]<=DivisorSigma[1, Product[Pow[n, i], {i, 1, s}]]+1, 0, 1], {s, 1, Length[f[n]]-1}]
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Jan 19 2013
